newsitem.title: UK: Dlr slides in Europe as yen and Swiss franc rally.
newsitem.headline: Dlr slides in Europe as yen and Swiss franc rally.

text.p: The dollar ended over one pfennig and one yen lower in Europe as jitters about Japanese foreign exchange intervention buoyed the yen and talk of a broad-based start to European monetary union lifted the Swiss franc.
Thin trading conditions in Europe exaggerated the intraday swings as most of continental Europe, including Germany, was out for the Ascension Day holiday.
The yen's recovery is being fuelled by what many perceive as thinly-veiled official warnings more yen weakness will be opposed.
"The Japanese are warming us up for the fact that interest rates there may change," said Tony Norfield at ABN Amro.

Norfield, who is a treasury economist at ABN Amro, said the Japanese authorities had clearly allowed market interest rates to tick higher as well as reminding traders the Bank of Japan has $220 billion of reserves with which to defend their currency.
"This has seen Japanese investors cut a lot of overseas bond positions and was probably partly behind sterling's fall today too," said Norfield.
At 1530 GMT, the dollar was trading at 123.70/80 yen compared with 124.90/95 late Wednesday. Against the mark, it was trading at 1.7069/74 compared with 1.7210/15 late yesterday.

The yen's latest push higher was fuelled by comments from senior Japanese Ministry of Finance official, Eisuke Sakakibara -- know in the markets as "Mr. Yen." Sakakibara said that based on past performances the dollar/yen's average annual range could allow its scope to go as low as 103 yen this year.
"For a man as clued-in to the market as Sakakibara, you don't mention specific levels like that without knowing their likely impact," said a trader at a U.S. house here.
On Wednesday, another Ministry of Finance official said Japan was prepared to use its huge foreign exchange reserves promptly if the yen continued to weaken excessively.
Dollar/yen has risen up to 10 percent this year alone to a 56-month high at 127.46 earlier this month.

Analysts said the dollar's plight was not helped by a benign assessment of inflation from the U.S. Federal Reserve in its regular Beige Book report late Wednesday, further dampening speculation of another imminent U.S. interest rate rise.

Sterling was a big loser in early trading, meantime, after a news report cited a ruling UK Labour Party source as saying a return to Europe's exchange rate mechanism at a central rate of 2.50 marks by 2001 was possible. Sterling was trading about 2.82 marks before the report and fell as low as 2.7654 on Thursday.

The UK Treasury later denied the talk but analysts said the more Euro-friendly tone of the new UK government would keep talk of a lower sterling target in the market. Others say interest rate speculation is shifting against the pound and the government will be happy with a weaker unit.

"Sterling's vulnerability does not come from the direction of poor policy credibility but from the size of the sterling overvaluation and the prospect of fiscal, not monetary tightening," said Avinash Persaud, head of currency research at JP Morgan. He said the European stance of the new government will also lead to a fall of the pound's EMU safe-haven status.

The fall of the dollar and the rising prospect of a broad-based EMU, possibly with Italy and the UK, helped the Swiss franc higher as the prospect of a weak euro pushed funds to the low-inflation haven of Switzerland, said analysts.
